issue.title: [BUG] Fixing broken conversions from nested data frame

labels.name: bugfix
labels.description: Fixes a known bug or removes unintended behavior

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Attempted fix of https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2381, of broken conversions from nested data frame to other types:

* `from_nested_to_multi_index` conversion was very brittle and sensitive wrt index names. I replaced the dozens of lines with a minor variation on `pandas.explode` (which also should be much faster)

Conditional on PR https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2970 to avoid duplicate columns coming out of `RandomIntervalSegmenter` which would break the new converter (but are not interface compliant).

Test for the duplicate column problem is introduced here:
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2969

body:
> Partial investigation indicates that the ripple effects may be caused by casting of dtype in pandas and numpy, where the wrong type may or may not cause things to break.

Oh no! not again! #2224

yes indeed, well spotted!
It seems similar to yours!

issue.title: [ENH] tsf loader mtype fix

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->


#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->
Introduces 2 major changes to the `load_tsf_to_dataframe`
1. metadata are returned as a dictionary and as separate values
2. output dataframe can either be the original return type or a multiindex/hierarchical mtype

#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [X] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.


<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->

body:
```python
X.reset_index(drop=True)
```
fixes the result

The `X` from `load_arrow_head()` is returning non-unique indexes which confuses `from_nested_to_long()`.

Should we reset in `from_nested_to_long()` or `raise ValueError`?
Add a check to `from_nested_to_long()` to ensure unique indexes? or make it resilient to the non-uniqueness?

Definitely fix the  `load_arrow_head()` so it outputs only the unique indexes when test and train datasets are merged into one.

thanks @ciaran-g!

Hm, I see - the problem is a non-unique input.

What I think we should then do:
* we should check whether the checks check that the indices are unique
* the converters should raise a warning if non-unique indices are passed
* and do the `reset_index` fix inside the conversion functions

Why: I think the longley data and conversions are used in a number of tests, estimators written by @TonyBagnall et al, and possibly by a number of users.
If we now let it raise `ValueError`, some of this code might break.
Instead, let's ensure it works with the broken input, and ensure that the `check` function would catch it.
we never user the longley data @fkiraly, nor long format converters at all. Also never use the merged data set, its why I changed the default return_X_y to true.

> we never user the longley data @fkiraly, nor long format converters at all. Also never use the merged data set, its why I changed the default `return_X_y` to true.

That's not right? It is used throughout `sktime`, for doc examples (which become tests via doctest) and some automated tests. Since it is one of the few on-board data sets that come multivariate.

The "original sin" here seems to be having created a data loader that, under certain circumstances, can return non-compliant data containers, but everyone will assume (since it is one of a few loaders) that the output is compliant, hence useable for testing!

Further, the issue is about the arrowhead data, which has the same problem.
